metadata.case_name: Kakumanu Ramanna (minor) through next friend v. Kakumanu (first defendant) and others

facts.text: Suit for partition of joint family properties instituted on April 2, 1942, in Court of District Munsif, Ongole, on behalf of minor Kakumanu Ramanna (age about 2 1/2 years) by maternal grandfather Rangayya as next friend.

First defendant is father of plaintiff; second and third defendants are sons of first defendant by deceased first wife; fourth defendant is second wife of first defendant and mother of plaintiff; fifth defendant is daughter of first defendant by fourth defendant.

Plaintiff alleged three grounds for partition: (1) ill-treatment and neglect to maintain mother and children (not established by lower courts); (2) sale of family properties to Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi for Rs. 2,300 on May 9, 1939, without necessity, to injure plaintiff; (3) items 2 and 11 purchased on June 1, 1938, and June 14, 1939, with joint family funds but sale deeds taken in names of second and third defendants to diminish assets.
Family in good circumstances with no debts.
Defendants filed written statements on June 20, 1942, claiming purchases of items 2 and 11 made with separate funds of second and third defendants; joint family had debts of Rs. 2,600.
Minor plaintiff died in January 1943; mother (fourth defendant) recorded as legal representative and transposed as second plaintiff.

District Munsif, Ongole, in O.S. No. 139 of 1946, on rehearing: sale and purchases anterior to birth of minor, no cause of action; items 2 and 11 not proved separate, belong to joint family; no debts; but no cause of action for partition; suit dismissed on December 23, 1946.
Subordinate Judge, Bapatla, in A.S. No. 188 of 1947: affirmed findings on items 2, 11 joint and no debts; sale/purchases prior to birth, suit not maintainable; appeal dismissed on January 28, 1949.

Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1815 of 1949: defendants falsely claimed items 2 and 11 as separate; interest adverse to minor; suit beneficial; preliminary decree for partition on April 10, 1953.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether the courts below concurrently found that the suit was not instituted for the benefit of the minor, and whether the High Court could reverse that in second appeal.
Whether the suit for partition abated upon the death of the minor plaintiff before the court decided if it was for his benefit, preventing continuation by his legal representative.
Whether institution of suit for partition by minor through next friend effects severance in status from date of suit (conditional on court finding it beneficial), or only upon decree.

petitioner_arguments.text: Concurrent finding by courts below that suit not instituted for benefit of minor; pure question of fact not liable to interference in second appeal.

Suit abates on minor's death before adjudication on benefit; minor incapable of volition; division in status only when court exercises volition on his behalf via decree; interest survives to coparceners, not heirs.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mitakshara law; Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma; Lalta Prasad v. Sri Mahadeoji Birajman Temple; Hari Singh v. Pritam Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Defendants acted adversely by denying minor's title to items 2 and 11 and claiming debts; suit beneficial to minor.

Suit for partition by minor stands on same footing as by adult; severance from date of suit conditional on court holding beneficial; does not abate on minor's death; legal representatives can continue.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma; Ramsing v. Fakira; Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal

court_reasoning.text: Finding of lower courts was misdirection; transactions showed adverse conduct post-birth via denial of title in written statements and trial; beneficial to minor to partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendants 1-3 combined to deny title to items 2 and 11; persisted in appeal; courts below held against them.

court_reasoning.text: Under Mitakshara, coparcener right to partition arises on birth; unequivocal intention via suit causes severance (Girja Bai); applies to minors via next friend; court checks benefit but severance from suit date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court does not create volition; recognizes intention expressed by next friend if beneficial.

court_reasoning.text: Chelimi Chetty erroneous; power to partition not exclusively court's; next friend/guardian can effect via suit/out-of-court; suit does not abate on death; actio personalis inapplicable as property suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal representatives can continue and prove benefit; severance relates back to plaint.

holdings.text: High Court could interfere with lower courts' finding as based on misdirection.

Suit for partition by minor through next friend effects severance in status from date of institution, conditional on court finding beneficial; does not abate on minor's death; continuable by legal representatives.
Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma and followers erroneous; Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma etc. correct.

precedents_cited.relevance: Every coparcener can sever status by unequivocal intention; suit for partition constitutes such.
Even dismissed suit effects severance; status separate upon assertion.
Held suit abates on minor's death; erroneous as court does not create severance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lalta Prasad v. Sri Mahadeoji Birajman Temple
precedents_cited.relevance: No alteration of status by minor's suit; only on decree.
Severance only on decree date for accounting.
Severance from suit date conditional on benefit; no abatement on death.
Coparcener right to separate at will.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balkishen Das v. Ram Narain Sahu
precedents_cited.relevance: Partition by relation binding on minor if beneficial.

statutes_cited.name: Mitakshara law (Hindu law)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs coparcenary rights to partition and severance of status.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Madras High Court's preliminary decree for partition; rejected appellants' contentions; held suit did not abate and severance effective from plaint date upon finding of benefit.

key_quotes.text: "the filing of a suit for partition is a clear expression of such an intention, and that, in consequence, there is a severance in status when the action for partition is filed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms Girja Bai principle applies to minors via next friend.

key_quotes.text: "when a court decides that a suit for partition is beneficial to the minor, it does not itself bring about a division in status. The court is not in the position of a super-guardian."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Overrules Chelimi Chetty; clarifies court's role.

key_quotes.text: "the true effect of a decision of a court that the action is beneficial to the minor is not to create in the minor proprio vigore a right which he did not possess before but to recognise the right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains severance relates back to suit institution.
